context: Recently, in-digester and post-digestion ammonia recovery has been investigated using methods such as gas-stripping coupled with acid absorption, membrane distillation, and struvite precipitation (Tao et al., 2016; Lu et al., 2015; Serna-Maza et al., 2015; Zhao et al., 2015; Zarebska et al., 2014). Unlike ammonia removal, ammonia recovery extracts ammonia from digestate and produces marketable products. Except for an integrated ultrafiltration, reverse osmosis and cold stripping process (Ledda et al., 2013), nevertheless, the research has not resulted in industry adoption due to economic feasibility concerns and technical challenges. In an effort to overcome these barriers, the authors developed a thermal stripping process (Tao and Ukwuani, 2015), in which both conversion of ammonium to free ammonia and stripping of free ammonia out of digestate were enhanced by thermal treatment. Thermal stripping occurs most efficiently at the boiling temperature, but there is no need to introduce a stripping gas. Water vapor and mists are trapped in the stripper while stripped ammonia was absorbed to sulfuric acid to produce crystalline ammonium sulfate, (NH4)2SO4. When the thermal stripping – acid absorption process is applied to a recirculation line of an anaerobic digester, the need to heat digesters can be eliminated or reduced due to heat recycling, thus making this energy-intensive process profitable (Anwar and Tao, 2016).
